We finish building a complex, flow-based case study that leverages the new @Shared property wrapper. Along the way we will flex recently added superpowers of the library, and we will experience firsthand how simple this new model of shared state can be.

entry.title: Shared State: The Solution, Part 1
entry.content:

Shared State: The Solution, Part 1

The various approaches of sharing state in the Composable Architecture are mixed bag of trade offs and problems. Is there a better way? We‚Äôll take a controversial approach: we will introduce a reference type into our state, typically a value type, and see what happens, and take it for a spin in an all new, flow-based case study.

entry.title: Shared State: The Problem
entry.content:
#268 ‚Ä¢ Monday Feb 26, 2024 ‚Ä¢ Subscriber-only

Shared State: The Problem

We tackle one of the biggest problems when it comes to ‚Äúsingle source of truth‚Äù applications, and that is: how do you share state? Let‚Äôs begin by analyzing the problem, and truly understanding what vague mantras like ‚Äúsingle source of truth‚Äù even mean, and then we will be in a good position to provide a wonderful solution.

Watch episode (48min)

entry.title: Point-Free Live: Observation in Practice
entry.content:
#267 ‚Ä¢ Monday Feb 19, 2024 ‚Ä¢ Subscriber-only

Point-Free Live: Observation in Practice

To celebrate our 6th anniversary we had another livestream! We updated an app from the most recent Composable Architecture tour to the latest observation tools, showed how these tools can improve UIKit-based apps, showed off some recent enhancements to the @Reducer macro, gave a sneak peek of a highly anticipated topic, and answered your questions along the way.

Watch livestream (1hr 54min)

entry.title: Observable Architecture: The Point
entry.content:
#266 ‚Ä¢ Monday Jan 29, 2024 ‚Ä¢ Subscriber-only

Observable Architecture: The Point

So what‚Äôs the point of observation in the Composable Architecture? While we have seemingly simplified nearly every inch of the library as it interfaces with SwiftUI, let‚Äôs zoom out a bit, explore how some integration tests that benchmark certain aspects of the library have changed, and migrate the Todos application we built in the very first tour of this library to the new tools.

Watch episode (27min)

entry.title: Observable Architecture: Observing Bindings
entry.content:
#265 ‚Ä¢ Monday Jan 22, 2024 ‚Ä¢ Subscriber-only

Observable Architecture: Observing Bindings

We have iterated on how bindings work in the Composable Architecture many times, but have never been fully happy with the results. With Observation, that all changes. By eliminating view stores and observing store state directly, we are free to totally reimagine bindings in the Composable Architecture, and get rid of even more concepts in the process.

Watch episode (19min)

entry.title: Observable Architecture: Observing Navigation
entry.content:
#264 ‚Ä¢ Monday Jan 15, 2024 ‚Ä¢ Subscriber-only

Observable Architecture: Observing Navigation

Observation has allowed us to get rid of a number of view wrappers the Composable Architecture used to require in favor of vanilla SwiftUI views, instead, but we still depend on a zoo of view modifiers to drive navigation. Let‚Äôs rethink all of these helpers and see if we can trade them out for simpler, vanilla SwiftUI view modifiers, instead.

Watch episode (22min)

entry.title: Observable Architecture: Observing Collections
entry.content:
#263 ‚Ä¢ Monday Jan 8, 2024 ‚Ä¢ Subscriber-only

Observable Architecture: Observing Collections

We can now observe struct, optional, and enum state in the Composable Architecture, but what about collections? Let‚Äôs explore what it takes to get rid of the ForEachStore wrapper view for a vanilla ForEach view instead, while still observing updates to collection state in the most minimal way possible.

Watch episode (53min)

entry.title: Observable Architecture: Observing Enums
entry.content:
#262 ‚Ä¢ Monday Dec 18, 2023 ‚Ä¢ Subscriber-only

Observable Architecture: Observing Enums

We‚Äôve made structs and optionals observable in the Composable Architecture, eliminating the need for ViewStores and IfLetStores, so what about enums? If we can make enums observable, we could further eliminate the concept of the SwitchStore, greatly improving the ergonomics of working with enums in the library.

Watch episode (43min)

entry.title: Observable Architecture: Observing Optionals
entry.content:
#261 ‚Ä¢ Monday Dec 11, 2023 ‚Ä¢ Subscriber-only

Observable Architecture: Observing Optionals

The Composable Architecture can now observe struct state, but it requires a lot of boilerplate. Let‚Äôs fix this by leveraging the @Observable macro from the Swift open source repository. And let‚Äôs explore what it means to observe optional state and eliminate the library‚Äôs IfLetStore view for a simple if let statement.

Watch episode (40min)

entry.title: Observable Architecture: Structural Identity
entry.content:
#260 ‚Ä¢ Monday Dec 4, 2023 ‚Ä¢ Subscriber-only

Observable Architecture: Structural Identity

One of the core tenets of the Composable Architecture is that you should be able to model your application‚Äôs state using simple value types, like structs and enums. However, the @Observable macro does not work with value types at all, and so in order to enhance the Composable Architecture with Observation we will need to contend with this issue and explore what it means for a struct to be observable.

Watch episode (43min)

entry.title: Observable Architecture: Sneak Peek
entry.content:
#259 ‚Ä¢ Monday Nov 27, 2023 ‚Ä¢ Free Episode

Observable Architecture: Sneak Peek

We‚Äôre about to completely revolutionize the Composable Architecture with Swift‚Äôs new Observation framework! But first, a sneak peek: we‚Äôll take the public beta (available today!) for a spin to see how the concept of a ‚Äúview store‚Äù completely vanishes when using the new tools.

Oh, and did we mention that the new observation tools in the library have been backported all the way back to iOS 13? This means you can use the tools immediately. ü§Ø

Watch episode (22min)

entry.title: Macro Case Paths: Part 2
entry.content:

Macro Case Paths: Part 2

We have now totally reimagined the design of our case paths library to create actual key paths for enum cases, but there is some boilerplate involved. Let‚Äôs create a macro that eliminates all of it and explore a few of the possibilities it unlocks.

Watch episode (55min)

entry.title: Macro Case Paths: Part 1
entry.content:
#257 ‚Ä¢ Monday Nov 13, 2023 ‚Ä¢ Subscriber-only

Macro Case Paths: Part 1

‚ÄúCase paths‚Äù grant key path-like functionality to enum cases. They solve many problems in navigation, parsing, and architecture, but fall short of native key paths‚Ä¶till now. Let‚Äôs close this gap using macros that generate actual key paths to enum cases.

We take all we‚Äôve learned about the Observation framework and apply it to a larger, more real world application: our rewrite of Apple‚Äôs Scrumdinger demo. We‚Äôll see what changes are easy to make, what changes are a bit trickier, and encounter a bug that you‚Äôll want to know about.

Watch episode (1hr 1min)

entry.title: Observation: The Future
entry.content:
#255 ‚Ä¢ Monday Oct 30, 2023 ‚Ä¢ Subscriber-only

Observation: The Future

We‚Äôve explored the present state of observation in Swift, so what‚Äôs the future have in store? Currently, observation is restricted to classes, while one of Swift‚Äôs most celebrated features, value types, is left out in the cold. Let‚Äôs explore a future in which observation is extended to value types.
